awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: FW-HTF-P: Personalized Wearable Cooling for Workers under Heat Stress
awd_abstract_narration:
Approximately 30 million U.S. workers are employed in occupations where the human body is regularly exposed to severe heat stress.  Heat stress can result from extreme environmental conditions and from high levels of metabolic activity often involved in these exposed occupations. Heat stress can substantially impair cognitive function, degrade physical performance and endurance, and elevate the risk of injury, illness and death. Although human workers are expected to continue to play major roles in these exposed occupations, technologies to mitigate their heat stress have not received much attention. To address this, the investigators explore the development of novel wearable cooling devices and will obtain preliminary data that will help assess and improve the efficacy, acceptability, and usability of the devices. The research team will engage other stakeholders to examine the socioeconomic impacts of the cooling devices and the potential needs for policy and other interventions to facilitate their widespread and equitable adoption.

The proposed work helps validate past discoveries in the field of thermoregulatory physiology: body heat is not lost to the environment equally from all body surfaces. A better understanding of regional differences in heat loss has implications for wearable technologies that can be used to prevent or treat heat stress in a way that is both feasible, effective, and accessible. The ultimate aim is to develop a disruptive technology for wearable cooling that is readily scalable.  The proposed work will also help advance fundamental understanding of the materials, thermodynamics, and heat transfer in a flexible cooling device.  Programs to broaden participation of undergraduate and graduate students, especially from economically disadvantaged and underrepresented groups, are an integral part of the proposed efforts.  The research project should serve as an attractive platform to encourage and excite K-12 students to pursue further education in science and engineering, given its significance in applications that can directly impact human lives, especially those employed in exposed occupations and their families.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Approximately 30 million U.S. workers, including outdoor construction workers, are employed in exposed occupations, where the human body is regularly exposed to extreme environmental conditions, in particular severe heat stress.  Heat stress can also result from high levels of metabolic activities often involved in many of these exposed occupations. Heat stress can substantially impair cognitive function; degrade physical performance and endurance; and elevate the risk of injury, illness and even fatality.

 

In this planning grant, we performed a fundamental study to develop novel wearable cooling devices and economic portable thermal sensors to help alleviate heat stress for future construction workers.  Our collaborators also performed human subject testing to obtain preliminary data that will help assess and improve the efficacy, acceptability, and usability of the cooling devices.

 

Our wearable cooling devices consist of thermally responsive insoles with a built-in smart switch and coolant channels. These insoles incorporate stimuli responsive soft materials (SRSMs) to control the coolant channels and extract heat from the feet in a temperature-responsive manner.  The team has found a suitable material, a liquid crystal elastomer (LCE), that meets the requirements for the smart switch, enabling coolant flow at elevated temperatures and blocking flow when the temperature drops. We constructed coolant channels integrated with LCEs and conducted preliminary functionality tests. These tests involved connecting the channels to a water pipe maintained at the physiological temperature to simulate flow and body temperature conditions. The smart switch demonstrated effective flow regulation in response to temperature changes within a narrow range. We have also advanced the preliminary design by integrating the device with a circulating cooling system and testing its interaction with the human body. This included modifying the channel material for better sealing and thermal conduction and applying realistic mechanical pressure to ensure consistent thermal regulation while enduring mechanical stresses. We also developed an economic portable sensor for the mean radiant temperature, which is a convenient measure of heat stress due to radiation from the ambient, such as solar radiation and its reflection and infrared radiation from the hot surrounding surfaces. Local and distributed measurements of the mean radiant temperature enabled by our sensor can help optimize the operation of cooling devices and inform the workers of local heat stress conditions in real time.

 

Overall, our work provides foundational insights into the design of thermally responsive wearable cooling systems and distributable sensors for the mean radiant temperature, paving the way for future refinement and practical implementation.  Anticipated broader impacts include reduction of worker occupational injury risks in the short run; reduction of work-related chronic illnesses and disability in the long run; reduced income inequality associated with heat-related work disruptions for workers in exposed occupations; and improved work productivity.  Our work also helps highlight the occupational health and productivity impacts of heat exposure to workers, employers, and the public at large.  Undergraduate students played active roles in the project, which helped them appreciate the significance of their education and research in applications that can directly impact human lives, especially those employed in exposed occupations and their families.
